summary: Computer Engineering + Quantitative Finance undergraduate at NUS with hands-on experience in backend systems, computer vision, and applied machine learning. Comfortable building datasets, training/evaluating models, and shipping full-stack products that integrate AI workloads.
story:
I started coding in Year 1 and quickly realised how much I enjoy building software that actually works. Since then, I’ve focused on software engineering and machine learning, especially where models and applications meet. I like working end-to-end, understanding how each component fits, and making things reliable and usable.

I’m also exploring a bit of quant on the side because I find the mix of data, markets, and modelling interesting. It’s an area I’m still learning, but I enjoy experimenting with ideas and seeing how they behave.

My long-term goal is to build a practical software product or business of my own. If that doesn’t work out, I’ll start a gym. For now, I’m focused on learning, shipping projects, and improving my craft as an engineer.

bullets: Design and build desktop and cloud features that enhance Autodesk products across Windows, macOS, and Linux.
Collaborate with cross-functional partners to solve integration challenges across SDKs and shared components.
Prototype and evaluate new technologies/algorithms to keep the platform efficient and scalable.
Drive code quality through design discussions, peer reviews, and performance-focused implementation.
Built CV pipelines for traffic-violation detection across surveillance video and large-scale datasets.
Iterated model performance and backend integration with cross-functional engineering teams.
Trained CNNs, RNNs, Transformers, and V-JEPA for temporal-spatial violation patterns; fine-tuned CLIP with LoRA.
Automated frame extraction, data labeling, and preprocessing for high-throughput workflows.
Integrated inference servers with REST APIs and achieved 85% precision / 70% recall / 20% FPR on V-JEPA collision detection.
Automated global fault categorization with Python scripts and LMStudio-powered local LLM calls.
Hit 95% classification accuracy and reduced customer-service workload by 90%.
Built VBA + Python pipelines for data cleaning and preprocessing.
